meeting_annotations.speaker: Nick Galati
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I I've started doing so so I I've looked into doing some Raman and some Flim imaging and so with Flim imaging you can look at metabolites like NADPH and NAD ratios and things like that. It's not particle tracking per se. It's more just trying to get a, you know, like a metabolic view of the cell. And with the Raman stuff, we've got a group that's working on surface enhanced Raman probes, which I think could potentially be tagged to to molecules. But what we've like it's just I I'd interested if anybody's actually gone further with Raman. We can't get around the integration time. So to study fast things, we just have to integrate for so long that it's not really a particle tracking thing. It might be more of a a cell migration type time scale on the minutes kind of time scale, but on this the second particle tracking in a cell type stuff, we haven't we haven't been able to do it. We we can characterize lipids and and DNA and things like that and mitochondria produce a pretty strong Raman signal.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Morteza Mahmoudi
meeting_annotations.transcript: I just want to add one thing from like a nanotechnology point of view, similar to what Jean mentioned is that like we have some particles that have some characteristics that can be probed by themselves. But uh at least at like at the nano site part of view when I basically try to tag other type of nanoparticles with a small molecules, what I see is that like the interaction of proteins with the surface of these nanoparticles gets changed. So what happens is that I have different nanoparticles in terms of their biological identity.
